_**The Greatest Showman**_ is a 2017 American [musical
film](/wiki/Musical_film "Musical film") directed by [Michael
Gracey](/wiki/Michael_Gracey "Michael Gracey") in his directorial debut,
written by [Jenny Bicks](/wiki/Jenny_Bicks "Jenny Bicks") and [Bill
Condon](/wiki/Bill_Condon "Bill Condon") and starring [Hugh
Jackman](/wiki/Hugh_Jackman "Hugh Jackman"), [Zac Efron](/wiki/Zac_Efron "Zac
Efron"), [Michelle Williams](/wiki/Michelle_Williams_\(actress\) "Michelle
Williams \(actress\)"), [Rebecca Ferguson](/wiki/Rebecca_Ferguson "Rebecca
Ferguson"), and [Zendaya](/wiki/Zendaya "Zendaya"). The film is inspired by
the story of [P. T. Barnum](/wiki/P._T._Barnum "P. T. Barnum")'s creation of
the [Barnum & Bailey Circus](/wiki/Ringling_Bros._and_Barnum_%26_Bailey_Circus
"Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus") and the lives of its star
attractions.

[Principal photography](/wiki/Principal_photography "Principal photography")
began in [New York City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City") in November
2016. The film premiered on December 8, 2017, aboard the [RMS _Queen Mary
2_](/wiki/RMS_Queen_Mary_2 "RMS Queen Mary 2"). It was released in the United
States on December 20, 2017, by [20th Century Fox](/wiki/20th_Century_Fox
"20th Century Fox") and grossed over $434 million worldwide, making it the
fifth-highest grossing live-action musical of all time.

_The Greatest Showman_ received mixed reviews, with praise for the
performances, music, and production values, but criticism for its [artistic
license](/wiki/Artistic_license "Artistic license"), with some reviewers
calling it "faux-inspiring and shallow".[4][5][6] At the [75th Golden Globe
Awards](/wiki/75th_Golden_Globe_Awards "75th Golden Globe Awards"), the film
received nominations for [Best Motion Picture – Musical or
Comedy](/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Motion_Picture_%E2%80%93_Musical_or_Comedy
"Golden Globe Award for Best Motion Picture – Musical or Comedy") and [Best
Actor – Musical or
Comedy](/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Actor_%E2%80%93_Motion_Picture_Musical_or_Comedy
"Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy") for
Jackman. For the song "[This Is Me](/wiki/This_Is_Me_\(Keala_Settle_song\)
"This Is Me \(Keala Settle song\)")", the film won the [Golden Globe Award for
Best Original Song](/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Original_Song "Golden
Globe Award for Best Original Song") and was nominated for [Best Original
Song](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Original_Song "Academy Award for Best
Original Song") at the [90th Academy Awards](/wiki/90th_Academy_Awards "90th
Academy Awards").[7]

## Plot[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Greatest_Showman&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Plot")]

In the late 19th century, [P. T. Barnum](/wiki/P._T._Barnum "P. T. Barnum")
and his troupe perform a show at the circus ("The Greatest Show"). In a
flashback to Barnum's childhood where he and his father Philo, a tailor, work
for the Hallett family, he becomes infatuated with their daughter, Charity.
Though Charity is being sent to [finishing school](/wiki/Finishing_school
"Finishing school"), Barnum reassures her they will not be separated. The two
keep in touch through letters until they meet again in adulthood ("A Million
Dreams"), eventually marrying and raising two daughters, Caroline and Helen,
in New York City ("A Million Dreams" reprise). They live a humble life; though
Charity is happy, Barnum dreams of more.

Barnum loses his job as a clerk at a shipping company after the company goes
bankrupt. Taking a risky bet, he takes out a large loan from a bank, deceiving
the bank into accepting his former employer's lost ships as collateral. He
uses this loan to buy [Barnum's American
Museum](/wiki/Barnum%27s_American_Museum "Barnum's American Museum") in
downtown Manhattan, an attraction showcasing various wax models. Initially,
sales are slow; on the suggestion of his children to showcase something
"alive", Barnum searches for "freaks" to serve as performers for his museum
("Come Alive"). This attracts a large audience despite protests and poor
reviews, prompting Barnum to rename his venture "Barnum's Circus."

Searching for ways to further his reputation amongst the upper class, Barnum
meets playwright Phillip Carlyle and convinces him to join his venture ("The
Other Side"). Carlyle is enchanted with Anne Wheeler, an African-American
trapeze artist, but he hides his feelings. During a trip, Carlyle arranges for
Barnum and his troupe to meet [Queen Victoria](/wiki/Queen_Victoria "Queen
Victoria"). Afterwards, Barnum meets [Jenny Lind](/wiki/Jenny_Lind "Jenny
Lind"), a famed Swedish singer, whom he convinces to perform in America, with
him serving as her manager. Lind's first American performance is a rousing
success ("Never Enough"). While Barnum gains favor with the aristocratic
patrons, he begins to distance himself from his original troupe, refusing to
socialize with them. Dejected, they decide to stand against their local
harassers ("This Is Me").

Carlyle and Wheeler attend the theater together one night, only to run into
Carlyle's parents, who are blatantly racist toward Wheeler, causing her to
leave. Carlyle chases her and tries to convince her that they can be together,
but she rejects him despite her feelings towards him ("Rewrite the Stars"). As
Barnum takes Lind on a US tour, Charity feels isolated from her husband as she
stays home with their daughters ("Tightrope"). While on tour, Lind begins
falling in love with Barnum, but when he refuses her advances, she calls off
the tour and kisses him at the end of her last show, which is photographed by
the press ("Never Enough" reprise). Barnum returns home to find his circus on
fire, caused by a fight between the protesters and the troupe. Carlyle, who
had tried to save Anne not knowing she had already escaped, is rescued by
Barnum amid the chaos but suffers severe burns. Most of the sets and props are
destroyed. Word of Lind's cancellation and Barnum's public intimacy also
reaches New York, resulting in his mansion being foreclosed upon and Charity
taking Caroline and Helen to her parents' home.

Depressed, Barnum retreats to a local bar, where his troupe find him there and
explain that despite their disappointments, they still consider themselves a
family that needs him. An inspired Barnum resolves to start anew and not let
ambition overtake his loved ones anymore. Meanwhile, the injured Carlyle wakes
in a hospital with Anne by his side and they share a kiss ("From Now On").

Barnum leaves and finds his estranged wife, and they decide to mend their
relationship. Faced with the financial difficulty of rebuilding the circus,
the recovering Carlyle steps in, offering to use his earnings from his share
of the circus's profits to rebuild it under the condition of becoming
partners, which Barnum happily accepts. As rebuilding the circus in its
original location would be too expensive, Barnum rebuilds it as an open-air
tent circus by the docks. The revamped circus is a huge success, and Barnum
gives full control of the show to Carlyle so he can focus on his family ("The
Greatest Show" reprise).

## Cast[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Greatest_Showman&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Cast")]

  * [Hugh Jackman](/wiki/Hugh_Jackman "Hugh Jackman") as [P. T. Barnum](/wiki/P._T._Barnum "P. T. Barnum"), an ambitious showman and entrepreneur. 
    * Ellis Rubin as Young P. T. Barnum 
      * Ziv Zaifman provides Young P. T. Barnum's singing voice.
  * [Zac Efron](/wiki/Zac_Efron "Zac Efron") as Phillip Carlyle, a [playwright](/wiki/Playwright "Playwright") who becomes Barnum's partner. His [character](/wiki/Composite_character "Composite character") is partly based on [James Anthony Bailey](/wiki/James_Anthony_Bailey "James Anthony Bailey").
  * [Michelle Williams](/wiki/Michelle_Williams_\(actress\) "Michelle Williams \(actress\)") as Charity Hallett-Barnum, the wife of P.T. Barnum. 
    * Skylar Dunn as Young Charity
  * [Rebecca Ferguson](/wiki/Rebecca_Ferguson "Rebecca Ferguson") as [Jenny Lind](/wiki/Jenny_Lind "Jenny Lind"), a famous Swedish singer known as the "Swedish Nightingale". 
    * Loren Allred provides Lind's singing voice.[8][9]
  * [Zendaya](/wiki/Zendaya "Zendaya") as Anne Wheeler, an acrobat, trapeze artist, W.D.'s younger sister and Phillip Carlyle's love interest. Her [character](/wiki/Composite_character "Composite character") is partly based on Ruth Louisa McCaddon.
  * [Keala Settle](/wiki/Keala_Settle "Keala Settle") as Lettie Lutz, a [bearded lady](/wiki/Bearded_lady "Bearded lady"). She is a composite character partly based on [Josephine Clofullia](/wiki/Josephine_Clofullia "Josephine Clofullia") and [Annie Jones](/wiki/Annie_Jones_\(bearded_woman\) "Annie Jones \(bearded woman\)").
  * [Yahya Abdul-Mateen II](/wiki/Yahya_Abdul-Mateen_II "Yahya Abdul-Mateen II") as W. D. Wheeler, an acrobat and Anne's brother.
  * [Natasha Liu Bordizzo](/wiki/Natasha_Liu_Bordizzo "Natasha Liu Bordizzo") as Deng Yan, a Chinese acrobat and blade-specialist.
  * [Paul Sparks](/wiki/Paul_Sparks "Paul Sparks") as [James Gordon Bennett](/wiki/James_Gordon_Bennett_Sr. "James Gordon Bennett Sr."), the founder, editor and publisher of the _[New York Herald](/wiki/New_York_Herald "New York Herald")_.
  * [Sam Humphrey](/wiki/Sam_Humphrey "Sam Humphrey") as [Charles Stratton](/wiki/General_Tom_Thumb "General Tom Thumb"), a dwarf performer who is also known by his stage name, General Tom Thumb. 
    * James Babson provides Stratton's speaking and singing voice.
  * Austyn Johnson as Caroline Barnum, Barnum's older daughter.
  * Cameron Seely as Helen Barnum, Barnum's younger daughter.
  * [Eric Anderson](/wiki/Eric_Anderson_\(actor\) "Eric Anderson \(actor\)") as Mr. O'Malley, a former thief whom Barnum employs at his circus to handle different tasks like staffing the front of the house, selling tickets, reading the reviews, fending off the protestors, producing the posters and promotional materials, and distributing the circus posters on everything.
  * Daniel Everidge as The Lord of Leeds, a heavyweight man who is based on Teodulo Valenzuela.
  * Timothy Hughes as the [Strongman](/wiki/Strongman_\(strength_athlete\) "Strongman \(strength athlete\)"), a man with enhanced strength who is based on [Angus MacAskill](/wiki/Angus_MacAskill "Angus MacAskill").
  * Shannon Holtzapffel as Prince Constantine, the Tattooed Man who is based off George Costentenus.
  * Luciano Acuna Jr. as Walter, the Dog Boy who is based on [Fedor Jeftichew](/wiki/Fedor_Jeftichew "Fedor Jeftichew").
  * Danial Son and Yusaku Komori as [Chang and Eng Bunker](/wiki/Chang_and_Eng_Bunker "Chang and Eng Bunker"), the "[Siamese Twins](/wiki/Siamese_Twins "Siamese Twins")."
  * Jonathan Redavid as [Frank Lentini](/wiki/Frank_Lentini "Frank Lentini"), the Three-Legged Man.
  * Nick Jantz as Jeff Harris, the Juggler.
  * Kenneth Chan as the [Human Cannonball](/wiki/Human_cannonball "Human cannonball")
  * Martha Nichols as Woman in Gold, a woman in gold clothing with gold spots on her.
  * Jeremy Hudson as The Elephant-Skinned Man, a man who is based on [Ralph Krooner](/w/index.php?title=Ralph_Krooner&action=edit&redlink=1 "Ralph Krooner \(page does not exist\)"). He was credited as "Dancer Oddity #3."[10]

  * [Will Swenson](/wiki/Will_Swenson_\(actor\) "Will Swenson \(actor\)") as Philo Barnum, a tailor and the father of P. T. Barnum.

  * Kathryn Meisle as Hannah Hallett, mother of Charity and mother-in-law of Barnum.

##
Production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Greatest_Showman&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Production")]

The project was first announced in 2009, with Jackman already set for the
title role.[11] In August 2011, [Michael Gracey](/wiki/Michael_Gracey "Michael
Gracey") was chosen to direct.[12] In 2013, Fox hired lyricists [Pasek and
Paul](/wiki/Pasek_and_Paul "Pasek and Paul") to write the songs.[13]

On June 15, 2016, [Zac Efron](/wiki/Zac_Efron "Zac Efron") began negotiations
to star in the film,[14] and in July 2016, [Michelle
Williams](/wiki/Michelle_Williams_\(actress\) "Michelle Williams \(actress\)")
was cast.[15][16][17][18] The film was choreographed by [Ashley
Wallen](/wiki/Ashley_Wallen "Ashley Wallen").[19]

###
Filming[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Greatest_Showman&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Filming")]

Rehearsals on the film began in October 2016 in [New York
City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City"), and [principal
photography](/wiki/Principal_photography "Principal photography") began on
November 22, 2016.[20][21]

### Post-
production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Greatest_Showman&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Post-production")]

In December 2017, it was reported that [James Mangold](/wiki/James_Mangold
"James Mangold"), who had worked with Jackman on several projects (including
2017's _[Logan](/wiki/Logan_\(2017_film\) "Logan \(2017 film\)")_), had been
brought in to serve as an executive producer during the film's post-
production. In an interview, director Michael Gracey noted, "There were eight
producers on this film, and it was amazing having one of them be a
filmmaker."[22]

## Music[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Greatest_Showman&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Music")]

### Musical
numbers[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Greatest_Showman&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Musical numbers")]

[Benj Pasek and Justin Paul](/wiki/Pasek_and_Paul "Pasek and Paul") wrote all
the songs appearing in the film.[23]

  1. "The Greatest Show" – Hugh Jackman, Keala Settle, Zac Efron, Zendaya
  2. "A Million Dreams" – Ziv Zaifman, Jackman, Michelle Williams
  3. "A Million Dreams" (Reprise) – Austyn Johnson, Cameron Seely, Jackman
  4. "Come Alive" – Jackman, Settle, Daniel Everidge, Zendaya
  5. "The Other Side" – Jackman & Efron
  6. "Never Enough" – Loren Allred
  7. "[This Is Me](/wiki/This_Is_Me_\(Keala_Settle_song\) "This Is Me \(Keala Settle song\)")" – Settle
  8. "[Rewrite the Stars](/wiki/Rewrite_the_Stars "Rewrite the Stars")" – Efron & Zendaya
  9. "Tightrope" – Williams
  10. "Never Enough" (Reprise) – Allred
  11. "From Now On" – Jackman

###
Soundtrack[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Greatest_Showman&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Soundtrack")]

Main article: [The Greatest Showman: Original Motion Picture
Soundtrack](/wiki/The_Greatest_Showman:_Original_Motion_Picture_Soundtrack
"The Greatest Showman: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack")

The soundtrack album is produced by [Greg Wells](/wiki/Greg_Wells "Greg
Wells"), [Justin Paul](/wiki/Justin_Paul "Justin Paul"), and [Benj
Pasek](/wiki/Benj_Pasek "Benj Pasek"), featuring the eleven tracks performed
by the cast. In the United Kingdom it became only the second album in 30 years
to achieve 11 consecutive weeks at number 1.[24] _The Greatest Showman_
now[_[when?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items
"Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers")_] draws level with
[Adele](/wiki/Adele "Adele")'s _[21](/wiki/21_\(Adele_album\) "21 \(Adele
album\)")_ for the longest unbroken run at the UK summit in the last 30 years.
The cast album is
now[_[when?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items
"Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers")_] at 910,000 combined units,
according to the Official Charts Company, made up of 420,000 physical copies,
186,000 [downloads](/wiki/Download "Download") and 186,000 streaming.[25]

##
Release[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Greatest_Showman&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Release")]

_The Greatest Showman_ held its premiere on December 8, 2017, aboard the [RMS
_Queen Mary 2_](/wiki/RMS_Queen_Mary_2 "RMS Queen Mary 2"), while it was
docked in [New York City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City"). The film was
then released in the United States on December 20, 2017.[26][27] Like
[Disney's live-action _Beauty and the
Beast_](/wiki/Beauty_and_the_Beast_\(2017_film\) "Beauty and the Beast \(2017
film\)"), a sing-along version of the film was released in the United Kingdom
on February 23, 2018.[28] The film had a limited [IMAX](/wiki/IMAX "IMAX")
release on February 2.

###
Marketing[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Greatest_Showman&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Marketing")]

On June 28, 2017, 20th Century Fox released the first international
[trailer](/wiki/Trailer_\(promotion\) "Trailer \(promotion\)") to promote the
film. On November 13, 2017, the second trailer was released.[29]

On December 17, 2017, [Fox](/wiki/Fox_Broadcasting_Company "Fox Broadcasting
Company") televised a live performance of "Come Alive" from [Warner Bros.
Studios](/wiki/Warner_Bros._Studios "Warner Bros. Studios") during its live
musical special _[A Christmas Story Live!](/wiki/A_Christmas_Story_Live! "A
Christmas Story Live!")_ (which was based on fellow Pasek and Paul work _[A
Christmas Story: The Musical](/wiki/A_Christmas_Story:_The_Musical "A
Christmas Story: The Musical")_). The number featured the film's stars and a
cast of 150 dancers.[30][31]

### Home
media[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Greatest_Showman&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Home media")]

In the United States, the film was released via digital download on March 20,
2018, and was released on Blu-ray, DVD and 4K Ultra HD on April 10, 2018.[32]
In the United Kingdom, the film was released first on digital download on
April 27, 2018, while Blu-ray, 4K Ultra HD and DVD copies went on sale on May
14. These versions include the sing-along version, two hours of behind-the-
scenes footage and music machine jukebox features.[33]

##
Reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Greatest_Showman&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Reception")]

### Box
office[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Greatest_Showman&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Box office")]

_The Greatest Showman_ grossed $174.3 million in the United States and Canada,
and $260.2 million in other territories, for a worldwide total of $434.5
million, against a production budget of $84 million.[3] It is the third
highest grossing musical ever in North America and globally, respectively, and
_[Deadline Hollywood](/wiki/Deadline_Hollywood "Deadline Hollywood")_
estimated the film would turn a profit between $50–100 million.[34]

In the United States and Canada, _The Greatest Showman_ was released alongside
_[Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle](/wiki/Jumanji:_Welcome_to_the_Jungle
"Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle")_ , and was projected to gross around $21
million from 3,006 theaters over its first six days.[35][36] It took in $2
million on its first day and $2 million on its second. Over the three day
weekend, it grossed $9 million (for a six-day total of $19 million), finishing
fourth at the box office, behind _[Star Wars: The Last
Jedi](/wiki/Star_Wars:_The_Last_Jedi "Star Wars: The Last Jedi")_ , _Jumanji:
Welcome to the Jungle_ and _[Pitch Perfect 3](/wiki/Pitch_Perfect_3 "Pitch
Perfect 3")_.[37] In its second weekend, the film grossed $15.5 million, again
finishing 4th at the box office.[38] The weekend-to-weekend increase of 76.3%
marked the largest ever for a film playing in over 3,000 theaters, and the
fourth biggest ever.[39][40] In its third week, the film dropped 11% to $14
million.[41]

The film made $13 million in its fourth weekend and $11 million in its fifth,
finishing 4th and 5th at the box office, respectively.[42] The film continued
to hold well in its sixth week of release, grossing $9.5 million and returning
to 4th place,[43] and again finished fourth in its seventh week, this time
grossing $7.8 million (a drop of just 18%).[44] It is the 13th highest-
grossing film that never reached first place at the American box office.[45]

### Critical
response[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Greatest_Showman&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Critical response")]

On [review aggregator](/wiki/Review_aggregator "Review aggregator") [Rotten
Tomatoes](/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes "Rotten Tomatoes"), the film has an approval
rating of 56% based on 208 reviews, and an [average
rating](/wiki/Average_rating "Average rating") of 6/10. The website's critical
consensus reads, "_The Greatest Showman_ tries hard to dazzle the audience
with a Barnum-style sense of wonder – but at the expense of its complex
subject's far more intriguing real-life story."[46] On
[Metacritic](/wiki/Metacritic "Metacritic"), the film has a weighted average
score of 48 out of 100, based on 43 critics, indicating "mixed or average
reviews".[47] Audiences polled by [CinemaScore](/wiki/CinemaScore
"CinemaScore") gave the film an average grade of "A" on an A+ to F scale,
while it earned a 70% "definite recommend" from [comScore](/wiki/ComScore
"ComScore").[37]

[Owen Gleiberman](/wiki/Owen_Gleiberman "Owen Gleiberman") of
[_Variety_](/wiki/Variety_\(magazine\) "Variety \(magazine\)") gave the film a
positive review, writing, "_The Greatest Showman_ is a concoction, the kind of
film where all the pieces click into place, yet at an hour and 45 minutes it
flies by, and the link it draws between P.T. Barnum and the spirit of today is
more than hype."[48] [Richard Roeper](/wiki/Richard_Roeper "Richard Roeper")
of the _[Chicago Sun-Times](/wiki/Chicago_Sun-Times "Chicago Sun-Times")_ gave
the film 3/4 stars, saying, "With all that corn and cheese and old-timey
sentiment, _The Greatest Showman_ ends up scoring some very timely social
arguments. P.T. Barnum himself would have approved the dramatic sleight of
hand."[49] Steve Persall of _[Tampa Bay Times](/wiki/Tampa_Bay_Times "Tampa
Bay Times")_ gave the film an 'A', and said, "_The Greatest Showman_ is the
feel-good movie the holiday season needs,"[50] while William Bibbiani of
[IGN](/wiki/IGN "IGN") gave _The Greatest Showman_ a score of 7.9/10, and
called the film, "wildly entertaining."[51]

Britton Peele of _[The Dallas Morning News](/wiki/The_Dallas_Morning_News "The
Dallas Morning News")_ said, "The story is interesting and the beats are well-
acted, but it's the musical numbers that make _The Greatest Showman_."[52]
Jackie K Cooper of _[HuffPost](/wiki/HuffPost "HuffPost")_ gave the film a
score of 10/10 and wrote, "You will be overwhelmed by the music and magic that
explode on the screen. The film has a message that should resonate with
today's world concerning acceptance and courage."[53] Hugh Armitage of
_[Digital Spy](/wiki/Digital_Spy "Digital Spy")_ said, "_The Greatest Showman_
is a broad and solid crowd-pleaser. An undemanding spectacle for all the
family."[54] Alan Jones of _[Radio Times](/wiki/Radio_Times "Radio Times")_
called it "A joyously uplifting potpourii of visual resplendence, stylish
choreography and solid gold magic, one engineered to approximate the lavish
spectacle the movie musical once offered."[55]

Sheila O'Malley of [RogerEbert.com](/wiki/RogerEbert.com "RogerEbert.com")
gave it 3.5/4, stating "_The Greatest Showman_ is an unabashed piece of pure
entertainment punctuated by memorable songs."[56] Douglas Davidson of CLTure
called the film, "An undeniable spectacle with a infectious soundtrack, a
movie that dazzles and delights."[57] [James
Berardinelli](/wiki/James_Berardinelli "James Berardinelli") of ReelViews gave
the film a 3/4 score, and said, "The film has show-stopping well-choreographed
numbers with catchy tunes,"[58] and Calvin Wilson of _[St. Louis Post-
Dispatch](/wiki/St._Louis_Post-Dispatch "St. Louis Post-Dispatch")_ called the
film "highly enjoyable."[59]

Carl Kozlowski of _[Pasadena Weekly](/wiki/Pasadena_Weekly "Pasadena Weekly")_
gave the film an 'A', calling it "Groundbreaking & grandly innovative."[60]
Sean P. Means of _[The Salt Lake Tribune](/wiki/The_Salt_Lake_Tribune "The
Salt Lake Tribune")_ gave _The Greatest Showman_ 3.5/4 stars, stating, "A
strong cast give emotional power to this romanticized, tune-filled
biography."[61] Manuela Lazic of _[Little White
Lies](/wiki/Little_White_Lies_\(magazine\) "Little White Lies \(magazine\)")_
gave it 4/5, saying, "_The Greatest Showman_ deserves to become a Christmas
classic. The film's severe romanticism and ridiculous but affecting enthusiasm
make it irresistibly life-affirming."[62] Pete Hammond of _[Deadline
Hollywood](/wiki/Deadline_Hollywood "Deadline Hollywood")_ gave the film 4 out
of 5 stars and called it, "A fantasia of song and dance, a joyous exercise in
pure entertainment that is made for the holiday crowd."[63]

Conversely, [Mick LaSalle](/wiki/Mick_LaSalle "Mick LaSalle") of the _[San
Francisco Chronicle](/wiki/San_Francisco_Chronicle "San Francisco Chronicle")_
gave the film a negative review, criticizing the songs and characters and
saying "There's idiotic, and there's magnificent, but _The Greatest Showman_
is that special thing that happens sometimes. It's magnificently idiotic. It's
an awful mess, but it's flashy. The temptation is to cover your face and watch
it through your fingers, because it's so earnest and embarrassing and
misguided – and yet it's well-made."[64] In a negative review for _[The
Hollywood Reporter](/wiki/The_Hollywood_Reporter "The Hollywood Reporter")_ ,
David Rooney wrote "This ersatz portrait of American big-top tent impresario
P.T. Barnum is all smoke and mirrors, no substance. It hammers pedestrian
themes of family, friendship and inclusivity while neglecting the fundaments
of character and story."[65]

Writing for _[Rolling Stone](/wiki/Rolling_Stone "Rolling Stone")_ , [Peter
Travers](/wiki/Peter_Travers "Peter Travers") gave the film 1.5 out of 4
stars, saying, "How do you cast a virtuoso Hugh Jackman as P.T. Barnum, spare
no expense in production values, add a score by Oscar and Tony winners Benj
Pasek and Justin Paul and still end up with the shrill blast of nothing that
is _The Greatest Showman_? Ask first-time director Michael Gracey, who cut his
teeth on commercials and music videos without ever mastering the crucial knack
of building snippets of musical comedy and drama into a satisfying whole."[66]
Justin Chang of the _[Los Angeles Times](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Times "Los Angeles
Times")_ wrote that the film's failures "are rooted in something deeper: a
dispiriting lack of faith in the audience's intelligence, and a dawning
awareness of its own aesthetic hypocrisy. You've rarely seen a more straight-
laced musical about the joys of letting your freak flag fly."[67]

## Historical
accuracy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Greatest_Showman&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Historical accuracy")]

Detailing the differences between the biography of Barnum, and the character
portrayed in the film, [Smithsonian](/wiki/Smithsonian "Smithsonian") magazine
called the film "pretty humbug." The magazine noted that one of the legacies
ascribed to the real Barnum was his profiting from marketing racism to the
masses, even though later in life he came to express some regrets.[89]
